div1.p: Strategy in application and nomination for Nobel Prize.

div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Dr. Santos, February 22, 1912
div1.opener:
Dr. Aristides Agramonte
K Street, Between 15th & 17th
Vedado, Habana.
TRANSLATION
Febr. 22/12.
Dear Dr. Santos:
div1.p:
I see that the matter of the NOBEL PRIZE is on the Order of
the Day for tomorrow. I believe a quorum is assured and nobody appears
opposed to a thing which cannot prejudice a third party and which, if
succesful, would be an honor for our country. Only to our Secretaries (a)
could it occur to compromise themselves in the manner which they did in
the last Council of Government (b).

Dr. Varona Suarez has promised me that as soon as the Academy
agrees to rectify the blunder or the Government completely abstains from part-
icipation of any kind, except to lend its moral support, which is in reality
all that can be accepted from it. All are convinced that the candidacy of
Dr. Finlay alone would be a failure, because of the opposition my friends of
the American Army would make, not because they esteem that the award is not
merited, but because they would consider it a slight on the work of the Army
Commission which I alone represent today because of the demise of my comrades.

Dr. Guiteras, who no doubt will assist at the Academy session,
knows all those points, although he sustains that the Government should part-
icipate in the presentation of canidates to the Tribunal of Awards. Nowhere
can I find that this is necessary, as he sustains, but it is not possible to
convince him until I receive a reply to the questions which I have directly
addressed to Sweden.

I go to Camaguey today and because of this I cannot get to
greet you.
div1.closer:
Yours, AGRAMONTE Dr. J. Santos Fernandez,
E. S. M. (Handed to you)
oooOooo
(a) Members of the Cabinet.
(b) The Cabinet.
Dear Doctor Hench:
The above translation, hastily made,
is not perfect but it is better than none
at all.
J. J. M.
